controlRequirement: Test the effectiveness of the incident response capability [Assignment: organization-defined frequency].

settings.description: Enables Attack Simulation Training in Microsoft Defender for Office 365 Plan 2 to conduct realistic but harmless phishing simulations and social engineering tests that evaluate the organization's incident response capability. Attack simulations test how users report suspicious messages, how security tools detect threats, how quickly alerts are generated, and how effectively the incident response team responds to simulated attacks. This directly implements incident response testing requirements by providing controlled testing of detection and response mechanisms.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Verify licensing: Attack Simulation Training requires Microsoft 365 E5 or Defender for Office 365 Plan 2
2. Navigate to Microsoft Defender portal (https://security.microsoft.com)
3. Go to Email & collaboration > Attack simulation training
4. Review Overview tab to familiarize with capabilities:
   - Recent simulations
   - Simulated users vs non-simulated
   - Training completion rates
   - Repeat offenders
5. Assign required permissions:
   - Attack Simulation Administrator: Full control
   - Attack Simulation Payload Author: Create payloads
6. Configure Settings tab:
   - Set up simulation launch preferences
   - Define repeat offender threshold (default: 2 consecutive compromises)
   - Configure end-user notifications
7. Ensure Safe Links and Safe Attachments policies allow simulation URLs
8. Create initial test simulation to validate platform functionality
9. Document attack simulation schedule and testing procedures
10. Integrate simulation results into incident response plan testing metrics

controlMappings.mappingRationale: Attack Simulation Training directly implements the requirement to test the effectiveness of the incident response capability. By simulating realistic phishing attacks and social engineering scenarios, organizations can test multiple aspects of their incident response: (1) User awareness and reporting behaviors, (2) Detection capabilities of security tools, (3) Alert generation and escalation procedures, (4) Incident response team notification and initial response, (5) Investigation and analysis procedures, (6) Containment and remediation effectiveness. Simulation results provide measurable data on incident response performance including detection rates, time to respond, user susceptibility, and process gaps - enabling continuous improvement of the incident response program as required by NIST 03.06.03.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Test the effectiveness of the incident response capability

settings.description: Configures and executes regular phishing simulation campaigns using various attack techniques to test incident detection and response procedures. Simulations use realistic phishing scenarios including credential harvesting, malware attachments, malicious links, and drive-by URLs. Each simulation tests whether users report suspicious messages, whether security systems generate alerts, and whether the incident response team detects and responds appropriately. Regular simulation campaigns provide ongoing testing of incident response effectiveness at defined frequencies.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Navigate to Microsoft Defender portal > Attack simulation training > Simulations tab
2. Click 'Launch a simulation' to create new simulation:
3. Select technique to test:
   - Credential Harvest: Tests password phishing response
   - Malware Attachment: Tests file-based threat detection
   - Link in Attachment: Tests multi-stage attack detection
   - Link to Malware: Tests URL-based threat response
   - Drive-by URL: Tests automated malware download scenarios
4. Configure simulation parameters:
   - Name simulation: 'Q1 2025 Phishing Test - Credential Harvest'
   - Select payload from library or create custom
   - Target users: Start with pilot group, expand to organization
   - Schedule launch: Immediate or scheduled
5. Configure training assignment:
   - Assign training to users who fall for simulation
   - Select training modules based on technique
   - Set training due date
6. Configure landing pages:
   - Customize message shown to compromised users
   - Include education on how to identify phishing
   - Add reporting instructions
7. Configure notifications:
   - Notify users before/during/after simulation
   - Deliver training based on user actions
8. Launch simulation and monitor progress
9. Document simulation schedule (recommend monthly or quarterly)
10. Review results to identify trends and improvement areas

controlMappings.mappingRationale: Phishing simulation campaigns provide structured, repeatable testing of the organization's incident response capability at defined frequencies. Each simulation tests the complete incident response chain: (1) User detection and reporting, (2) Security tool detection (Defender for Office 365), (3) Alert generation and notification, (4) Incident correlation and assignment, (5) Investigation procedures, (6) Containment and remediation actions. By conducting simulations using various attack techniques and analyzing the results (compromise rates, reporting rates, time to detect/respond), organizations can measure the effectiveness of their incident response capability, identify weaknesses, and track improvements over time - fulfilling NIST 03.06.03's testing requirements. Regular campaigns ensure ongoing validation of incident response readiness.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Test the effectiveness of the incident response capability at organization-defined frequency

settings.description: Enables automated simulation campaigns that run on defined schedules without manual intervention, ensuring consistent and regular testing of incident response capabilities. Simulation automations can be configured to launch randomized phishing simulations at specified frequencies (weekly, bi-weekly, monthly), automatically select payloads, target different user groups, and repeat for defined durations. Automation ensures that incident response testing occurs at the organization-defined frequency without requiring manual administration for each test.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Navigate to Microsoft Defender portal > Attack simulation training > Simulation automations tab
2. Click 'Create automation' to set up automated testing:
3. Configure automation details:
   - Name: 'Monthly Phishing Response Test'
   - Description: 'Automated testing of incident response capability per NIST 800-171 03.06.03'
4. Select social engineering techniques:
   - Choose multiple techniques to vary testing
   - Credential Harvest (most common)
   - Link in Attachment
   - Malware Attachment
5. Select payload strategy:
   - Randomize: System selects different payloads each run
   - Manual selection: Choose specific payloads to test
   - Recommend randomized for varied testing
6. Configure landing pages and training:
   - Use default Microsoft landing pages
   - Assign appropriate training modules
   - Set training due dates
7. Configure end-user notifications:
   - Notification timing (before, during, after)
   - Delivery preferences
8. Set simulation schedule:
   - Schedule type: Randomized or Fixed
   - Frequency: Weekly, Bi-weekly, Monthly, Quarterly
   - Start and end dates
   - Days/times for simulation delivery
9. Configure launch details:
   - Use unique payloads for each campaign
   - Target users: All users or specific groups
   - Enable 'Target repeat offenders' for focused testing
10. Submit automation and monitor execution
11. Review automation results regularly to track trends

controlMappings.mappingRationale: Simulation automation directly addresses the frequency requirement in NIST 03.06.03 by enabling organizations to define and automate their incident response testing schedule. By configuring automations to run at specific intervals (monthly, quarterly, etc.), organizations ensure that incident response testing occurs consistently at their defined frequency without relying on manual processes that may be forgotten or deprioritized. Automated campaigns provide continuous testing and trending data over time, enabling organizations to track improvements in incident response effectiveness across multiple test cycles. This automation ensures sustainable compliance with the testing frequency requirement and provides consistent measurement of incident response capability.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Test the effectiveness of the incident response capability at organization-defined frequency

settings.description: Provides comprehensive reporting and analytics on simulation results including user compromise rates, message reporting rates, training completion rates, repeat offenders, and simulation coverage. Reports measure the effectiveness of incident detection and response procedures by tracking key metrics: time from simulation delivery to user reporting, detection by security tools, alert generation, and incident response team actions. Detailed reports enable organizations to identify weaknesses in their incident response capability and track improvement trends over time.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Navigate to Microsoft Defender portal > Attack simulation training > Overview tab
2. Review key metrics dashboards:
   - Recent simulations status
   - Simulation coverage (simulated vs non-simulated users)
   - Training completion rates
   - Repeat offenders statistics
3. Access detailed reports on Reports tab:
   - Simulation impact: Shows user actions (reported, clicked, compromised)
   - Training efficacy: Measures training completion and impact on behavior
   - Behavior impact over time: Trends in user response
4. Drill into specific simulation results:
   - Click on simulation name to see details
   - View user-level data: who clicked, who reported, who was compromised
   - Review timeline of user actions
   - Export user list for targeted training
5. Use Attack simulation report (separate detailed report):
   - Access from Reports > Email & collaboration
   - View simulation details tab for individual campaign results
   - Check user coverage tab for testing gaps
   - Review training completion tab for training effectiveness
6. Generate executive summaries:
   - Export reports to PDF or CSV
   - Create presentations showing improvement trends
   - Document incident response testing outcomes
7. Set up regular report review meetings with security team:
   - Review simulation effectiveness
   - Identify users needing additional training
   - Assess incident detection and response times
   - Track progress against baseline metrics
8. Document findings and improvements in incident response plan
9. Use reports as evidence for compliance audits

controlMappings.mappingRationale: Simulation reporting and analytics are essential for evaluating the effectiveness of the incident response capability as required by NIST 03.06.03. Reports provide quantitative and qualitative data on all aspects of incident response performance: (1) Detection effectiveness (what % of simulations were detected by tools, reported by users), (2) Response time (time from simulation to detection/reporting), (3) User awareness levels (compromise rates, reporting rates, training completion), (4) Trend analysis (improving or declining response capability), (5) Gap identification (users/departments with poor response rates). This data enables organizations to determine whether their incident response testing demonstrates adequate capability, identify specific weaknesses requiring remediation, and track improvement over successive test cycles - providing evidence that incident response effectiveness is being actively measured and improved.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Test and evaluate the effectiveness of the incident response capability

settings.description: Provides security awareness training content integrated with simulation campaigns to educate users on recognizing and reporting security incidents. Training modules cover various topics including identifying phishing emails, recognizing social engineering tactics, proper incident reporting procedures, and secure behaviors. Training campaigns can be delivered proactively to all users or assigned automatically to users who fall for simulations. Effective training improves user participation in incident detection and reporting, which is a critical component of incident response capability.
settings.implementationGuide:
1. Navigate to Microsoft Defender portal > Attack simulation training > Content library tab
2. Review available training content:
   - Select 'Trainings' to see available modules
   - Over 85 training modules available in 30+ languages
   - Categories: Phishing, Password security, Malware, Social engineering
3. Create training-only campaigns (no simulation):
   - Go to Training campaigns tab
   - Click 'Create a training campaign'
   - Name: 'Quarterly Incident Reporting Training'
   - Select relevant training modules:
     * 'How to recognize and report phishing emails'
     * 'Security incident reporting procedures'
     * 'Social engineering awareness'
   - Target all users or specific groups
   - Set training due date
   - Configure notifications and reminders
4. Integrate training with simulations:
   - During simulation creation, assign training to compromised users
   - Select training based on simulation technique:
     * Credential harvest → Password security training
     * Malware attachment → File security training
     * Link-based → URL safety training
   - Set automatic assignment rules
5. Monitor training completion:
   - Review Training completion card on Overview tab
   - Track completion rates by department/user group
   - Send reminders to users with overdue training
6. Measure training effectiveness:
   - Compare simulation results before/after training
   - Track repeat offender rates after training
   - Measure improvement in reporting rates
7. Create custom training content if needed:
   - Include organization-specific incident reporting procedures
   - Add contact information for security team
   - Document internal escalation paths
8. Document training program as part of incident response testing
9. Report training completion rates in compliance documentation

controlMappings.mappingRationale: Security awareness training campaigns support incident response testing by ensuring users understand their role in the incident response capability. Effective incident response requires users to recognize potential security incidents (phishing, malware, suspicious behavior) and report them promptly to the security team. Training campaigns educate users on: (1) How to identify security incidents, (2) How and where to report incidents, (3) What information to provide when reporting, (4) The importance of timely reporting. By integrating training with simulation testing, organizations can directly measure whether training improves user incident detection and reporting rates - a key metric of incident response effectiveness. Training completion and effectiveness data provides additional evidence that the organization is testing and improving its incident response capability through user education programs.
controlMappings.nistRequirement: Test the effectiveness of incident response capability including user incident detection and reporting

implementationNotes: These settings represent the core incident response testing capabilities in Microsoft 365 that directly map to NIST 800-171 Rev 3 control 03.06.03. Attack Simulation Training requires Microsoft 365 E5 or Defender for Office 365 Plan 2 licensing. Organizations should define their incident response testing frequency in their security plan (recommended: monthly or quarterly simulations) and configure simulation automations to execute at that frequency. Testing should include multiple simulation techniques to comprehensively evaluate incident response across different attack vectors. Simulation results should be reviewed regularly by security leadership to identify trends, gaps, and improvements. Training should be integrated with simulations to continuously improve user incident detection and reporting capabilities. All testing activities and results should be documented as evidence of compliance with the testing requirement.
complianceReferences: Microsoft Defender for Office 365 Plan 2 - Attack Simulation Training
NIST SP 800-84 - Guide to Test, Training, and Exercise Programs for IT Plans and Capabilities
NIST SP 800-61 Rev 2 - Incident Response Testing and Training
